entry.et: Middle English shirte, from Old English scyrte; akin to Old Norse skyrta shirt, Old English scort short

def.dt: :a garment for the upper part of the body: as
:a cloth garment usually having a collar, sleeves, a front opening, and a tail long enough to be tucked inside trousers or a skirt
:all or a large part of one's money or resources lost his shirt on that business deal
:a jacket designed in the style of a shirt called also shirt-jac
:something intended to stir up or revive partisan animosity usually used in the phrase wave the bloody shirt
:a woman's close-fitting top made with a sewn-in or snapped crotch

entry.et: from its use in rough country

def.dt: :a usually loose-fitting cotton shirt with patch pockets
:a woman's shirt having a notched collar and often patch pockets
:a man's shirt especially for wear with evening dress
:a shirt suitable for wear with a necktie
:a shirt made of rough animal hair worn next to the skin as a penance
:one that irritates like a hair shirt
:a usually short-sleeved sport shirt with a colorful pattern
